image.altText: Pilot sitting in the cockpit of a small plane.

items.synopsis: Former US Marine pilot Daniel Duggan speaks publicly for the first time from his prison cell as he fights extradition to the United States over allegations he trained Chinese military pilots more than a decade ago.

title.children: Australian 'Top Gun' pilot speaks publicly for the first time since his arrest for allegedly training Chinese military pilots

image.altText: Black and white photo of large crowd of people, many squinting into the sun, aboard a boat, just visible.

items.synopsis: In 1975, Indonesia troops invaded Timor-Leste, targeting, among others, the Chinese Hakka ethnic minority. These people remember what the day was like.

title.children: Four decades ago soldiers killed their family and friends. Today they celebrate their own survival

image.altText: Three crashed vehicles with police at scene.

items.synopsis: A man has been charged with the alleged murder of three people who died in a crash between the Sunshine Coast and Gympie.

title.children: Man charged with murder after triple fatal Bruce Highway crash

image.altText: smiling older man looking at camera

items.synopsis: Good Samaritan Terry Bishop had been travelling to Brisbane on Friday to attend a family member's wedding. Family members say he was a man who would go out of his way to help anyone.

title.children: 'Absolutely devastated': Bruce Highway triple-fatal victim Terry Bishop had been travelling to family wedding

image.altText: The inside of a warehouse showing stacks of soft plastics, with some closer up.

items.synopsis: The major supermarkets have started sending samples of soft plastics overseas to be recycled, as they deal with the legacy of thousands of tonnes of stockpiled plastics from the collapsed REDcycle scheme.

title.children: Thousands of tonnes of soft plastics could be sent offshore, as supermarkets look to restart local recycling program

image.altText: A woman with brown short hair sits behind a microphone

items.synopsis: Senior public servant Kathryn Campbell resigns from the Department of Defence after coming under heavy criticism for her role in the Robodebt scandal.

title.children: Senior public servant in Robodebt scheme resigns from Department of Defence

image.altText: Sam Kerr with a bandage on her left calf at a Matildas training session in Brisbane.

items.synopsis: The extent of Sam Kerr's injury remains a mystery after Matildas youngster Kyra Cooney-Cross caused a brief panic by mistakenly saying her teammate had torn her calf.

title.children: Matildas play down panic over Kerr injury after teammate's slip of the tongue

image.altText: Three black women footballers wearing national team uniforms during a major tournament

items.synopsis: Four years ago, a record 13-0 scoreline sparked concerns around an expanded tournament. But the group stage so far has proved the doubters wrong.

title.children: Jamaica, Haiti, South Africa — what the World Cup group stage says about football's new order

image.altText: A woman wearing a blue shirt and gloves kneels in the dirt next to a bucket as she reaches into a hole with a small tool

items.synopsis: More than eight decades after Australian soldiers were transferred from temporary graves on the Kokoda Track to a wartime cemetery, a chance discovery reveals the task was never quite completed.

title.children: Deep in the PNG jungle, a landowner was upgrading his property. Then he made an astounding discovery

image.altText: A woman takes off a blue mask.

items.synopsis: COVID-19 isn't considered a public health emergency any more. But with so much sickness going around, experts say we need to think about how we can protect others.

title.children: The COVID restrictions of the past are (mostly) gone. So what's the etiquette if you've got the sniffles?

image.altText: Gina Rinehart smiles while standing in front of cattle pens

items.synopsis: The descendants of late mining magnate Peter Wright claim they are entitled to a bigger share of iron ore royalties based on an agreement struck with Lang Hancock in the 1970s, the WA Supreme Court hears.

title.children: Here's what happened on day one of the long-awaited showdown between mining heiresses

image.altText: Protesters demonstrate following a parliament vote on a contested bill.

items.synopsis: The bill passed by a 64-0 vote after opposition politicians abandoned the Knesset plenum in protest.

title.children: Israel's parliament ratifies contested law limiting Supreme Court powers, sparking protests

image.altText: The exterior of the Don Dale Youth Detention Centre, with barbed wire in the foreground.

items.synopsis: Changes to the criminal responsibility age in the Northern Territory will take effect on August 1, eight months after legislation passed the NT's parliament.

title.children: NT sets date for changing age of criminal responsibility, but advocates call for more changes

image.altText: A woman stands in red smoke, shouting into a megaphone

items.synopsis: Defying threats from protesters and a plea from the United States, Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has forged ahead with a bill that could push his nation towards a constitutional crisis. Here's how it all unfolded.

title.children: Israel's wild 24 hours explained: Heart surgery, a controversial vote and a country on the brink

image.altText: A commercial fridge filled with Coca Cola and other soft drinks.

items.synopsis: In April, the nation's doctors called again for the introduction of a tax on sugar-sweetened drinks. They are not alone, but here's an insight into why it's still not happening, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: Why hasn't Australia got a sugar tax? A look inside the machine of a subtle, ruthless war

image.altText: An older man and woman smile in front of a billboard showing a house that had been sold at an auction.

items.synopsis: Higher interest rates and rising house prices have not deterred migrants, retirees and first home buyers relying on "the bank of mum and dad" from buying property, despite data showing a lower number of property settlements.

title.children: The Lindemans bought their new home at auction — and paid in cash. They're part of a growing trend

image.altText: Zach Smith at a press conference.

items.synopsis: CFMEU national secretary Zach Smith says more than half a trillion dollars is needed to meet Australia's demand for social and affordable housing, and the only way to raise the funds is to introduce a "circuit-breaker" tax.

title.children: Construction union boss says tax on super profits needed to meet affordable housing demand

image.altText: James Heappey addressing UK and Ukrainian military personnel in Ukraine.

items.synopsis: Visiting UK Armed Services Minister James Heappey flags the possibility of British troops being eventually stationed in Darwin.

title.children: UK minister tells Australia Ukraine can win if support is kept up

image.altText: Actresses, dressed as Barbies, gather around Greta who is smiling and holding a laptop.

items.synopsis: Barbie is a certified smash hit at the box office, with Greta Gerwig breaking the record for the biggest opening weekend for a film directed by a woman. So, who is she, and what is she planning next?

title.children: Greta Gerwig has made box office history with Barbie. Here's your guide to her previous films

image.altText: Cael O'Donnell stands in a graveyard

items.synopsis: Scammers are using popular psychics' identities to trick people out of money on social media. Scamwatch is warning Australians to be vigilant online.

title.children: Rise in online scammers posing as psychics preying on Australian believers

image.altText: Gladys Berejiklian looking serious.

items.synopsis: ICAC inspector Gail Furness SC has written to former treasurer Matt Kean to advise him of the investigation after he wrote a letter complaining about the former premier's treatment last month, the ABC understands.

title.children: ICAC chief to probe delay in Gladys Berejiklian report, possible maladministration

image.altText: Wicks is standing in her place, holding a piece of paper and looking towards the Speaker (not in shot).

items.synopsis: The former federal MP for Robertson names herself at the centre of allegations about alleged abuse by a "NSW member of parliament spanning more than 5 years".

title.children: Liberal Party figure Lucy Wicks claims she received hundreds of 'abusive' texts from NSW MP

image.altText: A desk wall with a sign reading "Public health unit COVID-19. Contact tracing officer'. An out-of-focus figure sits at the desk.

items.synopsis: Third-party call centre workers contracted Victoria's health department were not properly screened, according to the state's information commissioner.

title.children: Privacy watchdog says Health Department failed to protect Victorians' data during COVID

image.altText: A young women in suit with a laptop

items.synopsis: Australia is in dire need of highly skilled researchers in the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) sector, but many report being stranded in their home country, unable to do their work here due to visa delays.

title.children: Australia is desperate for engineers like Sara — but she can't enter the country

image.altText: A teenage girl with blonde hair holds a mobile phone with both hands, with the phone in focus and her face obscured.

items.synopsis: A Mildura man has pleaded guilty to child exploitation and the transmission of child abuse material by encouraging a person in Thailand to send him illegal content.

title.children: Victorian man pleads guilty to seeking violent sex abuse images from source in Thailand

image.altText: a man in a simple black jacket sits behind microphones

items.synopsis: China's economy is in serious trouble. The country's property sector, once a powerhouse of national economic growth, is in meltdown — and there are predictions of worse to come, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: China's economy is in serious trouble — and it's bad news for Australia

image.altText: Pedro Sanchez puts his right hand over his heart and waves with his left hand.

items.synopsis: No clear winner emerges from a national election, leaving pro-independence Catalan and Basque parties as potential kingmakers as politicians look to form a bloc that can bring the required 176 seats for a majority.

title.children: Spain in stalemate after right fails to win predicted majority

image.altText: A man in a bucket hat rubs his face in frustration.

items.synopsis: England captain Ben Stokes says anyone who believes the team should have declared earlier at Old Trafford 'doesn't understand the game', as Australia retain the Ashes.

title.children: Stokes bristles at declaration critics and reveals his one regret as England fail to claim the Ashes back

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a suit pushes his fingertips together onstage in front of a black and white backdrop.

items.synopsis: Elon Musk and Twitter chief executive officer Linda Yaccarino have unveiled a logo for the social media platform that featured a white "X" on a black background as a replacement for the familiar blue bird symbol.

title.children: Twitter blue bird has flown as Musk, CEO say X logo is here

image.altText: An aerial view of wreckage of a school gymnasium in China

items.synopsis: Chinese state media reports a volcanic glass roof over a school gym collapsed, trapping a female volleyball team, with the heads of the company who installed the roof taken into custody.

title.children: Entire school gym roof collapses, killing 11 and trapping one
